metadata.title: Asymptomatic infection and atypical manifestations of COVID-19: comparison of viral shedding duration

abstract.text: Highlights · More than 25% of patients with COVID-19 were asymptomatic.
· Among patients with COVID-19, 26.1% presented anosmia, and 22.6% complained of ageusia with median duration of 7 days.
· Mean duration of SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding was 24.5 days.
· Irrespective of clinical manifestations, all patients with COVID-19 showed prolonged viral shedding.

body_text.text: to evaluate the prevalence of asymptomatic infection, anosmia (smell loss) and ageusia (taste 8 loss) among patients with mild COVID-19 in a residential treatment center (RTC). We also 9 compared the duration of SARS-CoV-2 viral shedding between groups with different clinical 10 manifestations.
An observational cohort study was conducted for 199 patients with COVID-19 in a RTC at

Among 199 patients with COVID-19, male was 34.7% and mean age of the patients was 26 38.0 years (Table 1) . Most patients (187, 94.0%) were healthy without chronic medical 27 conditions. Among 199 patients, 26.6% were asymptomatic. In the early study, asymptomatic
This study has some limitations. Anosmia and ageusia were subjective symptoms.
Olfactory test was not performed, and quantitative scale of olfactory dysfunction was not 58 measured. In addition, viability of SARS-CoV-2 detected by PCR was not proven using viral

FIGREF0.text: infectivity during the incubation period with rapid transmission. 2 Some 4 patients with COVID-19 are asymptomatic, while others complain of atypical symptoms 5 including loss of smell and taste sense. 3 However, there is insufficient data on the prevalence 6 of asymptomatic infection and atypical manifestations of COVID-19. In this study, we aimed 7

FIGREF1.text: Gyeongju, Gyeongsangbuk province, Republic of Korea (ROK). The RTC was introduced to 13 care patients with mild COVID-19 for the efficient distribution of limited medical resources 14 during large epidemic in early March 2020. Data on demographic findings, symptoms, and 15 duration of viral shedding were collected. The patients were interviewed about initial 16 symptoms and their duration in detail. Real-time PCR (RT-PCR) to detect SARS-CoV-2 was 17 performed every 2-7 days. Duration of viral shedding was considered as time from diagnosis 18 date to the day before first negative conversion of two consecutive negative results of RT-19 PCR. RT-PCR was conducted using Allplex 2019-nCoV assay (Seegene, Seoul, South Korea).

FIGREF2.text: Statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 20.0 program. Mann-Whitney U test was 21 performed to compare the duration of viral shedding between groups with different clinical 22 manifestations. P-value < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

FIGREF3.text: 28 cases accounted for 10.7% (3/28) of COVID-19 cases in the ROK. 1 Asymptomatic proportion 29 of COVID-19 was estimated as 17.9% (95% credible interval, 15.5-20.2%) on the Diamond 30 Princess cruise ship, Japan. 4 Among clinical manifestations, cough (41.2%) was most 31 common, followed by rhinorrhea and nasal stuffiness (30.2%). Of note, 26.1% (52/199) of 32 patients presented anosmia, and 22.6% (45/199) complained of ageusia. Thirty-eight (19.1%) 33 patients complained of both anosmia and ageusia. Duration of anosmia and ageusia ranged 2 34 -28 days (median, 7 days) and 3 -28 days (median, 7 days), respectively. Recently, 35 substantial number of patients with COVID-19 were reported globally to have developed 36 anosmia or hyposmia. 3,5 Among 59 hospitalized patients with COVID-19, 33.9% reported 37 olfactory or taste disorder in Italy. 3 This is consistent with current observations: among 146 38 symptomatic patients, 35.6% developed anosmia and 30.8% had ageusia in this study. 39 Mechanism of anosmia and ageusia induced by SARS-CoV-2 infection was not elucidated. 40 Upper respiratory infection is one of the most common causes of olfactory dysfunction. 6 41 Coronavirus 229E was detected in nasal discharge of a patient with post-viral olfactory 42 dysfunction. 7 SARS-CoV spread in the brain via the olfactory bulb in human angiotensin-43 converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) transgenic mice model. 8 SARS-CoV-2 use ACE2 for cell entry 44 and ACE2 is widely expressed in the oral tissues, especially in tongue epithelial cells. 9 45 Epithelial cells in salivary gland ducts were reported as early target cells of SARS-CoV in 46 5 macaques model. 10 It may be possible that viral tropism and distribution of ACE2 contribute 47 to the development of anosmia and ageusia in patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection. Further 48 research would be required on the mechanism of post-SARS-CoV-2 infection olfactory and 49 taste dysfunction. 50 Among the study population, mean duration of viral shedding was 24.5 days. Duration 51 of viral shedding was longer in symptomatic patients than in asymptomatic patients (25.2 52 days versus 22.6 days, p < 0.01) (Table 2). Particularly among symptomatic patients, those 53 with chest pain released the virus significantly longer (30.0 days versus 25.0 days, p = 0.01). 54 Prolonged viral shedding was also found in patients who complained of sputum (26.8 days 55 versus 24.6 days, p = 0.03).

FIGREF4.text: 59culture. However, this study is valuable in that it can provide detailed information about60 asymptomatic infections and atypical manifestations such as smell or taste dysfunction in 61 patients with COVID-19. 62 In conclusion, all patients with COVID-19 showed prolonged viral shedding irrespective 63 of clinical manifestations. Asymptomatic patients have potential to spread SARS-CoV-2 64 without recognition. Thus, mask wearing, hand hygiene and social distancing would be 65 important to control the viral transmission.

FIGREF5.text: JYS analyzed the data with responsibility for its integrity and prepared the 68 manuscript. All authors contributed to the conception and design of the study and to the 69 interpretation of data.
